ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Occasionally, lectures were delivered on-campus with the option for students to attend in-person if they wanted to.
live virtual lecture and optional TA homework help
Did a few of the lectures, we had an in-person option in Hastings Hall.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The physics (statics and dynamics) of buildings, objective and subjective considerations for structural engineering. This class was super insightful! It definitely changed how I move through the world in terms of the physical architecture that encompasses our lives.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strenghts: TA's were so helpful
weaknesses: class material was difficult and the teacher went through the information really quickly, sometimes did not take the time to explain things clearly

Strengths are a lot of cohesion between physics concepts and the assignments and exams. It felt like everything we learned had real value in knowing how to make safe buildings. Weaknesses were that without attending the homework sessions with TAs, it was often hard to know how to approach the assignments. The lectures didnt always match up with what the assignments demanded. More clarity would have helped student learning.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: difficult to work in groups to study for exams and work on psets

Having consistent homework help sessions with the TAs was successful. This created a space to ask any questions we had. This was crucial given how difficult it is to engage with lectures remotely. The lectures could have been improved through interactive problem solving (working step by step by engaging students) or doing short exercises in break out rooms and comparing as a group.

If possible, I think it would be better to use a program that allows the professor to hand write more easily. I think calculations would be much easier to follow if they were written as they were taught rather than just typed on the presentation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Good SC credit if you are good with trigonometry and want to learn about how skyscrapers/bridges/etc carry loads.
not if you do not have a physics background. the material was hard and not for beginners. class moved too quickly

Yes, I would recommend it as a class to take with friends (or make new friends)! Dont be afraid to go to office hours and ask as many questions as you need. Its really rewarding, but it definitely requires you to take responsibility for your own learning. Divest from getting a good grade, focus on your own growth and learning and you will do great no matter what.
If you have to take it for the architecture major or already have a good grasp of physics, yes, but otherwise no.
